content.body: I think that's the point of the `|> ...` operator? `x |> ...[a, b, c]` is essentially `x |> a(^) |> b(^) |> c(^)`.
content.formatted_body: I think that's the point of the |> ... operator? x |> ...[a, b, c] is essentially x |> a(^) |> b(^) |> c(^).

I think that's the point of the |> ... operator? x |> ...[a, b, c] is essentially x |> a(^) |> b(^) |> c(^).

content.body: It would possibly be better written as `getCustomerNameSteps = [...]`

content.body: Also, this would be impossible for a type system like TypeScript to statically type in any meaningful way. You'd have to wait for the `|> ...` to instantiate generics, meaning you have no type inference when composing functions in the array.
